name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
prompt:
The new generation external memory encompasses an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions:

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment.
  2. After selecting these indices, you then replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2.

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Arrange the array a utilizing no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output

1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3]

  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

The new generation external memory encompasses an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. On the other hand, it does allow you to cut out any segment of the given array and perform a cyclic shift on it by any offset you choose. You can then insert the shifted segment back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions:

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment.
  2. After selecting these indices, you then replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2.

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2]. The newly shifted segment replaces the original elements, taking the place of the initial segment position. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Arrange the array a utilizing no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element, but instead allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment, 2. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        # We will perform at most n shifts
        for i in range(n):
            # Find the first unsorted segment
            for l in range(n - 1):
                if array[l] > array[l + 1]:
                    # Find the right boundary of the unsorted segment
                    r = l + 1
                    while r < n and array[r - 1] > array[r]:
                        r += 1
                    # Perform a cyclic shift on this segment
                    d = 1  # We can choose any d, here we choose 1 for simplicity
                    segment = array[l:r]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[l:r] = shifted_segment
                    actions.append((l + 1, r, d))
                    break
            else:
                # If no unsorted segment is found, the array is sorted
                break
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    # Output interface
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the cyclic shift actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        # We will perform cyclic shifts until the array is sorted
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the segment that needs to be shifted
                l = i + 1
                r = array.index(sorted_array[i], l - 1) + 1
                d = r - l

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # If the number of actions exceeds n, break
                if len(actions) > n:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    array = list(map(int, input().split()))
    test_cases.append((n, array))

# Call the function
results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

# Output interface
for result in results:
    k, actions = result
    print(k)
    for action in actions:
        print(' '.join(map(str, action)))
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and the details of each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        # Simple strategy: perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment [i+1, n]
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of actions and details of each action.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                
                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                # Check if the array is sorted
                if array == sorted_array:
                    break
        
        # Ensure the number of actions does not exceed n
        if len(actions) > n:
            actions = actions[:n]
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # We will use a simple selection sort-like approach with cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            # Find the minimum element in the unsorted part of the array
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            # If the minimum element is not already in the correct position
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                # The segment is from i+1 to min_index+1 (1-based index)
                # The offset is min_index - i (0-based index)
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[i:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[i:r] = shifted_segment
                
                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        # Ensure the number of actions does not exceed n
        if len(actions) > n:
            actions = actions[:n]
        
        # Append the result for this test case
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface

# Output interface

    print(k)

        print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # We will perform a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is not optimized for the minimum number of shifts but ensures the array is sorted
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                # We choose l = i + 1, r = min_index + 1, d = min_index - i
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                segment = array[i:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[i:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    array = list(map(int, input().split()))
    test_cases.append((n, array))

# Call the function and get the result
results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

# Output interface
for result in results:
    k, actions = result
    print(k)
    for action in actions:
        print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts each test case array using cyclic shifts and returns the actions taken.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k (number of actions) and a list of actions.
        Each action is a tuple (l, r, d) representing the segment boundaries and the shift offset.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1  # Shift by 1 to the left

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # If the array is sorted, break early
                if array == sorted(array):
                    break

        # Append the result for this test case
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input().strip())
        array = list(map(int, input().strip().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: list[tuple[int, list[int]]]) -> list[tuple[int, list[tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """
    Sorts each array in the test cases using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions (l, r, d) for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift on the array
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                array[l-1:r] = segment[d:] + segment[:d]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        array = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts on segments.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1  # Shift by 1 to the left

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # If the number of actions reaches n, break
                if len(actions) >= n:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Output interface
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a more strategic sorting using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                l, r = i + 1, min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of an array to the left by a specified offset, effectively rearranging the elements within that segment.

    'segment'
    Explanation: A segment refers to a contiguous subarray defined by two indices, l and r, within the array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means we can perform up to n shifts to sort the array.
    Implementation: Ensure that the number of shifts does not exceed n by keeping a counter and checking it against n.

# [degree adverb]
    'arbitrary'
    Explanation: The indices l and r, as well as the offset d, can be chosen freely within their respective constraints.
    Implementation: Use loops or conditional logic to explore different combinations of l, r, and d to achieve sorting.

# [code logic]
    - Initialize a counter for the number of shifts.
    - For each test case, check if the array is already sorted. If so, return 0 shifts.
    - Otherwise, iterate through the array to identify segments that need shifting.
    - Perform cyclic shifts using list slicing and concatenation.
    - Keep track of the number of shifts and ensure it does not exceed n.
    - Output the number of shifts and their descriptions.

# [edge case]
    Input: [1, 2]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Input: [3, 3, 3]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: All elements are identical, so the array is considered sorted.

    Input: [10^9, -10^9]
    Output: 1
    Explanation: A single shift can sort this array by swapping the two elements.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted or if all elements are identical will naturally handle these cases.

We will implement a function that sorts an array using cyclic shifts. The function will iterate over the array and perform cyclic shifts to sort the array in ascending order. We will use a simple approach that ensures the number of shifts does not exceed the length of the array. The function will handle multiple test cases and output the required format for each test case.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of an array to the left by a specified offset, effectively rearranging the elements within that segment.

    'segment'
    Explanation: A segment refers to a contiguous subarray defined by two indices, l and r, within the array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed should not exceed the length of the array, n. This ensures that the sorting process is efficient and within the given constraints.
    Implementation: Ensure that the number of shifts performed is tracked and does not exceed n.

# [degree adverb]
    'arbitrary'
    Explanation: The indices l and r, as well as the offset d, can be chosen freely within their respective constraints.
    Implementation: Allow flexibility in choosing l, r, and d within their valid ranges.

# [code logic]
    - Initialize a counter to track the number of shifts performed.
    - For each test case, check if the array is already sorted. If so, output k = 0.
    - If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
    - Perform cyclic shifts on identified segments, updating the array and incrementing the shift counter.
    - Ensure the number of shifts does not exceed n.
    - Output the number of shifts and their details for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case with maximum possible shifts:
    Input: [3, 2, 1]
    Output: 3
    Explanation: Each element needs to be shifted to achieve sorting.

    Test case with repeated elements:
    Input: [2, 2, 1]
    Output: 1
    Explanation: Only one shift is needed to sort the array.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted and performing shifts as needed will handle these cases effectively.
examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
